title: Matt Wright moved to specialty prison unit with air-con, basketball court | ABC NEWS
description: It's been just two months since Netflix star Matt Wright was jailed in the Northern Territory for attempting to interfere with a police investigation into a fatal helicopter crash. Now sources say the high profile inmate has been moved out of the general prison population in Darwin, into an air conditioned unit with access to a pool table and basketball court. Most inmates at the Darwin Correctional Centre face overcrowding and oppressive heat, now questions are being asked about how the system handles high profile prisoners.  Roxanne Fitzgerald has this report for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Why Australians are falling behind | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Australians' pay rises are not keeping pace with the rising cost of living. New data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has confirmed workers have been going backwards.  The Wage Price Index (WPI) for the 12 months to December 2025 rose 3.4 per cent — lower than inflation for the same period. Because wages are not rising faster than inflation it means "real wages" are falling. Private sector pay went up 3.4 per cent, while public sector workers saw their wages increase by 4 per cent.  Melbourne sheet manufacturer Catten Industries says the pressures of wages and input costs to manufacture have made it very difficult for the business to be competitive. "It puts pressure on our costs because obviously people want more money to be able to make ends meet at the end of the day," he says. "All of my family work in the business as well, but included in that we've got 37 other families that all rely on our business to be successful." #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-18/wage-price-index-lags-inflation-real-wages-of-workers/106356432  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: CCTV captures moment of Merrylands stabbing attack | ABC NEWS
description: A man charged with murder has faced court after one person was killed and two others injured in a stabbing attack in Sydney's west.  25-year-old Setefano Mooniai Leaaetoa escaped mental health care 10 days prior to the attack in Merrylands, health authorities confirmed. Graphic security footage shows the moment of the attack, which police say was random. title: Health insurance loopholes leave customers thousands out of pocket | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Private health insurance premiums are set to rise by more than four percent, the largest rise since 2017. The increases this year are supposed to cover rising private hospital costs as some struggle to stay afloat.  But for some patients, their policies are covering less each year, especially when it comes to accidents and joint replacements.  Some 360,000 people have downgraded their policies from gold since 2020. Brett Heffernan from the Australian Private Hospitals Association says customers choosing to downgrade had become a regular occurrence during the cost-of-living crisis, but it also suited insurers because silver policies were still lucrative, but with far more exclusions.  PHA chief executive Rachel David said it was up to consumers to be aware of policy exclusions and read their disclosure statements closely.  "There are probably ways in which the health funds can do better in explaining what accident cover actually entails, but any product that you buy that's less than top hospital cover will have exclusions," she said. Accident inclusion insurance typically gives patients access to gold-level benefits, like joint replacements, in the case of an accident.   #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-18/private-health-patients-discover-exclusions-downgrade-policy/106325324  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: LNG giant Santos pledges to free up supply for the domestic market in 2027 | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Oil and gas giant, Santos says it won't renew third-party contracts in international markets, which will free up some gas supply for the Australian market in 2027. MST Financial senior energy analyst, Saul Kavonic says the decision could be seen as a proactive move ahead of the government's incoming gas reservation policy. He says the company's international contracts have contributed to pushing up prices for energy on Australia's east coast. Santos has also announced 10% of its workforce - or about 400 jobs - will be cut, and its Australian portfolio will face a strategic review. The announcements were made as Santos revealed its half-year profit fell by $US818 million, down 33% from a year ago. #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Sydney HungryPanda workers say Chinese police intimidating families over pay disputes | ABC NEWS
description: Sydney riders for delivery service HungryPanda, who have been considering protesting or refusing to work, say police in China have been making threats and putting pressure on their families back home.  Labor senator Tony Sheldon, who has long advocated for the rights of gig workers in Australia, said the allegations were "obviously concerning".  The ABC has no evidence that HungryPanda or anyone connected to the company are behind an effort to stymie protests. title: Fears Iranians executed following 'forced confessions' on state TV | ABC NEWS
description: Venus Hosseini-Nejad and Peyvand Naeimi were taken from their workplaces by Iranian security forces in January and later forced to confess on state TV to arranging protests their families say they were never part of.   Their families told ABC reporter Nassim Khadem these youths — who are members of the Baha'i' religious minority and for decades have faced persecution in Iran — are being falsely accused and used as "scapegoats". Their families say the pair have been transferred from a detention facility to prison and fear they could face the death penalty.  Early this week, US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency estimated more than 7,000 people have been killed and there have been almost 54,000 arrests in this wave of protests. A group of doctors in Iran reported in late January that there could have been as many as 30,000 people killed by the regime over two days of protests alone. title: Japan PM sworn in after landslide election victory | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Japan's prime minister Sanae Takaichi has been sworn in for a second time and officially confirmed by lawmakers as the country's leader. The win for Ms Takaichi comes as tensions continue to simmer with China. Donna Weeks is an emeritus professor at Musashino University Tokyo and she gave 'The World's' Yvonne Yong an update on Japan's ongoing tensions with Beijing. title: Day two of peace talks between Russia and Ukraine conclude | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Trilateral peace talks between the US, Russia and Ukraine have taken place in Geneva, with concerns raised by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy over what is required to secure a peace deal. Mr Zelenskyy has accused US President Donald Trump of trying to push Ukraine into giving up territory in order to reach a deal with Russia. Michael Bociurkiw is a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council and joined The World's Yvonne Yong to discuss the latest round of negotiations.
